contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox UK place |country = Scotland |official_name= Onich |scots_name= |gaelic_name=Omhanaich |population= |os_grid_reference= NN0298761 |map_type= Lochaber |latitude=56.7051 |longitude=-5.2199 |unitary_scotland= [[Highland (council area)|Highland]] |lieutenancy_scotland= |constituency_westminster= |constituency_scottish_parliament= |post_town= |postcode_district = PH33 |postcode_area= PH |dial_code= }} '''Onich'''{{Pronunciation-needed}} - at one time Ounich - ([[Scottish Gaelic language|Gaelic]]: ''Omhanaich'') is a settlement on the east shore of [[Loch Linnhe]], [[Scotland]] and, together with [[North Ballachulish]] at the entrance to [[Loch Leven (Highlands)|Loch Leven]], forms [[Nether Lochaber]]. ==Climate== As with the rest of the [[British Isles]] and Scotland, Onich experiences a [[maritime climate]] with cool summers and mild winters. Rainfall is high, approaching 2000mm a year on average. Onich holds the record for highest temperature reported, {{convert|32.1|C|F}},<ref>{{Cite web | publisher = [[MetOffice]] | url= http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/climate/uk/ns/ | title = 1995 Temperature}}</ref> for this part of Scotland (also the furthest north such a high value has been recorded in the British Isles). {{Weather box |location = Onich 1971-2000, 12m asl (Sunshine, Rainfall
